awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CDS&E: ReaxFF2: Efficient and Scalable Methods for Long-time Reactive Molecular Dynamics Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to enable long-time simulations of reactive molecular systems through efficient
and scalable techniques. Long-time reactive simulations are critical for several scientific problems
such as catalysis, battery interfaces, biological simulations involving water, and emerging
areas like surface oxidation and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) growth. However, progress on
these fronts is limited because long-time simulations of large-scale systems are very difficult, if
not impossible, to perform using existing methods. The Reactive Force Field (ReaxFF) method is in principle  
ideally suited for this purpose. However, the short time steps required in current ReaxFF simulations 
and the computationally expensive force field formulation limit ReaxFF's temporal capabilities to 
narrow simulation time ranges. This project aims to overcome such limitations by creating ReaxFF2,
which will extend time scales by one to two orders of magnitude - thus making large-scale, 
long-time RMD simulations accessible to a wide community. Codes developed will be made publicly 
available and results from this project will be highlighted on a dedicated website, and they will also be 
incorporated into workshops by the PIs.

In creating ReaxFF2, the PIs will enhance the Reax force field formulation significantly, and develop 
innovative algorithms and software implementations for scalable simulations. More specifically, 
alternative ReaxFF interactions will be formulated to eliminate sharp derivatives in energy terms 
and enhance ReaxFF time step lengths by at least a factor of four. To accelerate the dynamic charge 
distribution models needed in RMD, scalable parallel preconditioning techniques for the iterative 
solvers will be developed. A task parallel approach to compute interactions, hierarchical problem 
decomposition, vectorization of the key kernels, and use of mixed precision arithmetics constitute
the main techniques that will be utilized to fully leverage the performance capabilities of large
computer clusters. Finally, capabilities of accelerated RMD concepts in the proposed ReaxFF2 
formulation will be evaluated and inlined trajectory analysis tools for RMD will be developed 
to facilitate the study of long-time RMD simulations. This project will significantly enhance the PIs' 
software development, community building,  and sustenance efforts for the RMD community. Codes, 
functional forms, and parameter sets developed will be made publicly available, enabling fast and 
accurate modeling of diverse reactive systems beyond the scope of this project. For community outreach, 
results from this project will be highlighted on a dedicated website, and they will also be incorporated 
into workshops by the PIs.

This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Division of Materials Research 
and the Division of Chemistry within the NSF Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Computational chemical methods enable us to simulate chemical and physical interactions between atoms and molecules and as such provide invaluable insights in material and molecular response, providing new routes to material and molecule design and testing new concepts before embarking on often costly experimental synthesis and characterization. The computational chemical method active at the atomistic/molecule scale can be roughly divided into two categories quantum mechanics (QM) and empirical force field (EFF) based methods. The QM methods are more rigorous and more transferable  but the high computational cost of QM methods make them currently only applicable to relatively small systems, typically smaller than 500 atoms, and very short timescales, typically in a picosecond (10-12 seconds) scale. Many material/molecular systems require substantially larger system sizes and longer timescales. EFF methods based on empirical, often simplified, equations and fittable parameters, making them much faster - more than 1,000,000 times - than QM methods, enabling simulations on millions of atoms and nano to microsecond (10-9 to 10-6 seconds) which enable much more direct communication with experiment. The EFF methods can be divided into two categories, non-reactive EFFs, which do not allow for bond breaking and formation, and reactive EFFs, which do allow for bond rearrangement and can, as such, simulate chemical events.

The ReaxFF method is amongst the most versatile of the currently available EFF concepts, enabling simulations on covalent, ionic and metallic compounds and their interfaces. However, this capability comes at an expense - ReaxFF is a relatively complex EFF method, and as such is 50-100 times slower than many of the simpler reactive and non-reactive EFF methods. In this project, we have developed methodology that closes this performance gap. This was done in four different ways:

1)    Develop improved accelerated molecular dynamics (MD) methods. Accelerated MD methods allow us to sample chemical events faster. Examples of these methods include parallel replica sampling, were multiple simulations are started side-by-side to improve the probability of sampling rare reactive events, and hyperdynamics, were energies associated with difficult to sample reaction barriers are systematically lowered to increase their accessibility. We have demonstrated that a combination of these two acceleration classes provide substantial acceleration beyond each individual class, thus providing access to microsecond level reactive molecular dynamics.

2)    Coupling reactive and non-reactive force fields. In many cases, only a small subsection of the system is chemically active and the rest of the system can be treated as non-reactive. As such, we developed Machine-Learning based communication channels between ReaxFF and popular non-reactive EFFs ? AMBER (specialized in biomolecules) and OPLS (specialized for polymer systems. These ReaxFF-hybrids enable very substantial speedups  for predominantly non-reactive systems (like enzymes and surface-catalysis) reaching speedups of 30 times or better.

3)    Speed up force field development time. ReaxFF is a complex method with many highly correlated parameters. As such, ReaxFF force field training is traditionally expensive. We have developed machine-learning assisted methods that help evaluate these parameter correlations and as such speed up their optimization process. We obtained dramatic speedups froin ReaxFF training times, going from days-to-minutes, which makes development of ReaxFF for more complex material combinations a viable concept.

4)    Enable longer ReaxFF time steps. Traditionally, ReaxFF molecular dynamics simulations had to be run with a very short (0.25 femtosecond, 10-15 seconds) timestep. We found that for many systems - in particular metallic and ionic systems - these timesteps can be increased by up to a factor of four. For covalent systems, we identified the origin of this small time-step requirement, this is related to relatively sharp derivatives in the ReaxFF energy description when new bond are formed. This provides a pathway to re-shaping ReaxFF for these covalent systems to also allow longer timesteps for covalent molecules and materials.

 

Together, these four improvements have greatly increased the ReaxFF accessible time-scales and have shortened the ReaxFF development times, enabling better connectivity between ReaxFF and experiments and opening the door for treating more complex materials and molecular combinations with ReaxFF. This, in turn, will enable better collaborations between modeling and experimental groups in new material and molecule design, leading to reductions in development times, especially in scientific domains that involve complex material interfaces, like batteries, semiconductors, biomolecule/material interfaces and additive manufacturing.
